concept.title: EGL Reference Implementation Component
concept.shortdesc: The EGL Reference Implementation component implements the minimum EGL functionality to support OpenWF composition. It does not implement the EGL functionality required to support the use of the Khronos rendering APIs, such as OpenGL ES and OpenVG. Typically device creators replace the reference implementation with a fully functional implementation of their own.

The Reference Implementation implements eglGetProcAddress() , which supports retrieving OpenWF-C extension functions.

Calling any of the unsupported APIs panics the client with the EEglPanicNotSupported panic code and the return value and EGL error code are undefined. This behavior deliberately does not conform to the EGL specification. It is intended to make it easy to detect errors in the platform configuration—for example, where the intention was to use a fully-functional EGL implementation instead of the Reference Implementation.

section.title: Private signaling function
section.p: Signaling is often used by both a third party application and its middleware API, such as OpenWF-C. However, once the middleware API calls the eglSignalSyncKHR() standard signaling function and obtains the error code using eglGetError(), the error code is not available to the application.

The following private signaling function returns the error without generating the error code. This is an implementation-specific function, which gives the OpenWF-C implementation a mechanism for calling into the EGL implementation.
section.codeblock: EGLint egl_Private_SignalSyncNOK( EGLDisplay dpy, EGLSyncKHR sync, EGLenum mode)
section.p: Generally when the same vendor implements both EGL and OpenWF-C, the vendor will implement their own private functions.
Note: The extension name of this private signal function is EGL_NOK__private__signal_sync, which can be obtained using eglQueryString().

section.title: Thread handling
section.p: The Reference Implementation allows the supported EGL APIs to be used from multiple threads within the same process. The Reference Implementation maintains the process and thread state in order to conform to the correct behavior described in the EGL specification. Access to process-wide objects is serialized and protected by mutex to prevent race conditions.

The Reference Implementation uses its own heap to allow the creation, access and destruction of process-wide objects from any thread. This includes the EGLDisplay and EGLSync objects. The heap is created in a local chunk.

For simplicity, the Reference Implementation supports only one display: EGL_DEFAULT_DISPLAY. A request to obtain any other EGLDisplay returns EGL_NO_DISPLAY. EGLDisplay is a process-wide resource that can be accessed from any thread. Its behavior follows the EGL specification for eglGetDisplay(), eglInitialize() and eglTerminate().
Each client thread can have its own EGL error. Error handling and thread state management follows the EGL specification for eglGetError() and eglReleaseThread().
